alert.note: Alert for Coos; Grafton (New Hampshire) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued February 27 at 4:14PM EST until February 27 at 5:15PM EST by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: The National Weather Service in Gray Maine has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Northwestern Oxford County in western Maine... Northwestern Somerset County in west central Maine... Northwestern Franklin County in western Maine... Coos County in northern New Hampshire... Northeastern Grafton County in northern New Hampshire... * Until 515 PM EST. * At 412 PM EST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from 28 miles north of Jackman to 18 miles northeast of Pittsburg to 19 miles northwest of Haverhill, moving southeast at 30 mph. HAZARD...Whiteout conditions. Zero visibility in snow and wind gusts up to 40 mph. SOURCE...Radar and webcams. IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel. This includes Interstate 93 between mile markers 95 and 131. Locations impacted include... Berlin, Littleton, Lancaster, Bethlehem, Colebrook, Lincoln, Jackman, Eustis, Coburn Gore, Rangeley, Haverhill, Franconia, Andover, Errol, Dixville, Stratford, Pittsburg, Woodstock, Seboomook and Grafton. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel is not advised during this dangerous snow squall. Rapid visibility reduction and potentially icy roads are likely to lead to accidents. Consider delaying travel until the squall passes your location. If traveling, pull off to a safe location and turn your headlights on. Road temperatures are above freezing, but sharply colder temperatures following the snow will cause any water or slush to quickly freeze on roads and sidewalks. Untreated road surfaces will become extremely slippery. Reduced speeds and increased distance between vechicles is advised.
